title: Gothic style font
content:
Hey guys, I am not sure what font this is, any ideas? Thanks

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901224551im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2_6196.jpg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [2.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901224551/http:/typophile.com/files/2_66.jpg) | 25.59 KB |
author: snipa21

comments.content:
Didn't find a close match, but Testament has the same feel:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/testament/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901224551/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/testament/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/testament/")
thank you for your suggestion. I believe that font will do!

A few more suggestions, from the realm of free fonts:

[http://www.fontspace.com/astigmatic-one-eye-typographic-institute/uncial...](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901224551/http:/www.fontspace.com/astigmatic-one-eye-typographic-institute/uncial-antiqua "http://www.fontspace.com/astigmatic-one-eye-typographic-institute/uncial-antiqua")  
 [http://www.fontspace.com/rick-mueller/grange](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901224551/http:/www.fontspace.com/rick-mueller/grange "http://www.fontspace.com/rick-mueller/grange")

Good suggestions Kevin.  
Grange is the name used for a circa 1900 [just a guess as to date] Art Nouveau font found at p. 53 of Dan X. Solo's big catalog of his typeface purchases, but I don't know if this was the original name or the original designer or foundry. The unusual word "Grange" seems to have originated as a term for a farming estate belonging to a monastery but in the context of circa 1900 it may have referred to "The National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry" See wiki at [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_National\_Grange\_of\_the\_Order\_of\_Patrons...](http://web.archive.org/web/20140901224551/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_National_Grange_of_the_Order_of_Patrons_of_Husbandry "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_National\_Grange\_of\_the\_Order\_of\_Patrons\_of\_Husbandry") which includes a link to a colorful poster from 1873. Unfortunately Wiki says nothing about a font called Grange.  
Don
